abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Poverty Reduction Support Credits Project (PRSC) for Zambia
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: success was more noticeable in areas which
            coincided with Government's own priorities and where
            Bank had other instruments to engage outside the Poverty
            Reduction Budget Support (PRBS) framework. This is quite
            evident in the declining overall performance of the
            Government on Performance Assessment Framework (PAF)
            indicators in the past few years. There are several reasons
            behind this conclusion. One, the PAF document itself is the
            outcome of protracted negotiations and compromises between
            different groups of donors and the Government. As such it
            reflects the minimum common denominator as to what can be
            achieved and is unlikely to be a true reflection of
            Government's most strongly held priorities. Two, the
            context of budget support in Zambia has changed; ODA has
            declined dramatically as a share of Government's
            resources and unless the PAF mimics Government's
            strongly held priorities, it will have limited impact. The
            Bank should manage transitions within the Bank team more
            systematically. This is indeed a very general point but in
            this particular case it became very important. The
            Bank's absence from key PAF revision discussions due to
            staff transition had significant implications for the PRSC.
            It led to a misalignment between PAF and PRSC and strained
            relations between the Bank, donors and government.
